c74object.name: bach.round
c74object.digest: Round llll elements to a value
c74object.description: Calculates and outputs integer multiples of llll elements.

objarg.name: multiple
objarg.description: The optional argument is the rounding multiple. See the number message to know more.

method.name: bang
method.description: Performs the rounding with the most recently received input data.

method.name: llll
method.description: An llll in the first inlet is considered as the llll whose elements must be rounded. Each number inside the llll is rounded to the inserted multiple (see number message) and the modified llll is output.

method.name: number
method.description: A number in the second inlet sets the rounding multiple. All numbers of lllls coming from the left inlet will be rounded to multiples of this number. This number also determines the type of the output numbers: if this is an integer, all output numbers will be integers; if this is a float all output numbers will be float; if this is a rational, all output numbers will be rationals or integers. The default rounding multiple is 1 (integer).

attribute.name: nearest
attribute.description: If this attribute is set to 0, only lower multiples of the inserted elements are output (i.e. the abstraction works like the "floor" function). If this attribute is set to 1 (default) lower and higher multiples are both considered (and the one nearest to the original value is taken).

attribute.name: out
attribute.description:
The out attribute is a sequence of characters identifying the outlet types (one character for each llll outlet). Characters can be one of the followings:
n (default): 'native' output: faster and more precise between bach objects, but unreadable by standard Max objects (an "bach.llll" message appears instead).
t: 'text' output: slower and limited in size, but readable by standard Max objects. A plain llll in text format is a generic Max message.
x: disabled output (nothing is output)
p: 'portal' output: only used by bach.portal to intercept the @out attribute specified while creating the abstraction (see bach.portal).
The native output is recommended, unless communication with standard Max messages is needed. Disabling unused outputs can be useful if extreme optimization of the patch is needed.
